    library(ryx)
#> Warning: replacing previous import 'MASS::select' by 'dplyr::select' when
#> loading 'ryx'
library(MASS)

    ryx Package

    Introduction

    The ryx package give you tools to calculate and visualize correlations within a given data set. The main function is the ryx() function. Additional functions to support ryx include print.ryx(), summarize.ryx() and plot.ryx().

    Main Function

    The ryx function prints a table of correlations between a dependent variable y and one or more independent x variables. The format of the function is ryx(data, y, x, digits=3). Data is a data frame, y is the name of a numeric variable in the data frame, x is a character vector with the names of one or more numeric variables in the data frame, digits indicates the number of decimal places to print (3 is the default). If the user does not indicate x, the function will return the correlation of y with every other numeric variable in the data frame.

    Example 

    ryx(mtcars, y = "mpg", x = c("hp", "wt", "disp", "cyl", "am", "gear"))
#>      variable          r        p sigif
#> cor1       wt -0.8676594 1.29e-10   ***
#> cor3      cyl -0.8521620 6.11e-10   ***
#> cor2     disp -0.8475514 9.38e-10   ***
#> cor        hp -0.7761684 1.79e-07   ***
#> cor4       am  0.5998324 0.000285   ***
#> cor5     gear  0.4802848   0.0054    **

    Print Function

    The print function takes correlations created by the ryx function and prints a table of correlations that notes when the p value is < 2e-16.

    Example 

    x <- ryx(Boston, y="medv")
x
#>       variable          r        p sigif
#> cor10    lstat -0.7376627 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor4        rm  0.6953599 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor8   ptratio -0.5077867 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor2     indus -0.4837252 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor7       tax -0.4685359 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor3       nox -0.4273208 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor       crim -0.3883046 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor5       age -0.3769546 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor1        zn  0.3604453 <2.0e-16   ***
#> cor9     black  0.3334608 1.32e-14   ***
#> cor6       dis  0.2499287 1.21e-08   ***

    Summary Function

    The summary function takes correlations created by the ryx function and prints a summary of the median correlation, the range,and how many variables are significant at the p < 0.05 level.

    Example 

    x <- ryx(Boston, y="medv")
summary(x)
#> Correlating medv with lstat rm ptratio indus tax nox crim age zn black dis. The median absolute correlation was 0.427 with a range from -0.738 to 0.695. 11 out of 11 variables were significant at the p < 0.05 level.

    Plot Function

    The plot function takes correlations created by the ryx function and prints a plot of r values.

    Example 

    x <- ryx(Boston, y="medv")
plot(x)
